Title: The internet and internationalization of smaller manufacturing enterprises
Source title: Journal of Global Marketing
Affiliations: Department of Finance, College of Business and Economics, University of Wisconsin-Whitewater, 800 West Main Street, Whitewater, WI 53190, United States; Department of Marketing and International Business, Umeå School of Business and Economics, Umeå University, SE-901 87 Umeå, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Moini, H., Department of Finance, College of Business and Economics, University of Wisconsin-Whitewater, 800 West Main Street, Whitewater, WI 53190, United States; Tesar, G., Department of Marketing and International Business, Umeå School of Business and Economics, Umeå University, SE-901 87 Umeå, Sweden
Abstract: One of the most frequently discussed topics in the current international business literature is the impact of the Internet on the internationalization of smaller manufacturing enterprises (SMEs). The study was carried out through a mail survey of the top executives of 125 Wisconsin firms. It examined 10 research hypotheses on internal and external factors which had been identified by previous research to influence the internationalization of SMEs through the Internet. Research findings conclude that the scope of internationalization of SMEs through the Internet is affected by internal factors, such as managements' perceptions of the effectiveness of their web sites as a marketing tool, lack of experience, and SMEs' potential usage of the Internet. © 2005 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Tech scared vs. Tech savy: Which kind of print shop owner are you?
Source title: Instant and Small Commercial Printer
Affiliations: PrinterPresence, Lincoln, NE, United States
Authors with affiliations: Starr, T., PrinterPresence, Lincoln, NE, United States
Abstract: Integrating the Internet into marketing and business practices challenges small business owners nationwide, and print shop owners are no exception. Using the Internet to maximize a shop's potential requires determining what role the Internet will play in the marketing plan. On one side, print shop owners fear change. They typically are "tech scared." Their counterparts consider themselves "tech savvy" because they grasp innovation quickly. Regardless of the category one finds himself, there still is potential for integrating a Web site into the printing business.

Title: Effects of the internet on the marketing communication of service companies
Source title: Journal of Services Marketing
Affiliations: Växjö University, Växjö, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Lagrosen, S., Växjö University, Växjö, Sweden
Abstract: Purpose The purpose is to gain an understanding of how traditional service companies use the internet in their marketing communication and what effect the internet has had on their use of other marketing communication channels. Design/methodology/approach Multiple case studies have been carried out at 19 Swedish service companies. Findings The findings show that three different communications strategies are used depending on the scope of internet use and the extent to which the companies utilise relationship marketing. Small or decentralised companies use the personalised relationship communication strategy. Large companies have the option of using either the mass relationship communication strategy or the mass transaction communication strategy. The characteristics of the strategies and their respective effects on the other marketing communications tools are described. Research limitations/implications The conceptualisation of the communications strategies provides a framework that gives added understanding and is useful for further studies. Practical implications The presentation of the strategies and their implications should be useful for managers of service companies when planning their communication activities. The managers will benefit from making a conscious choice between the strategies and considering their features and implications. Originality/value The conceptualisation of the internet communications strategies provides a novel view of the communications options for service firms. This framework is useful for further research and for managers of service firms. © 2005, Emerald Group Publishing Limited
Author Keywords: Internet; Marketing communications; Relationship marketing; Services; Sweden

Authors: Nielson J.F., Host V., Mols N.P.
Title: Adoption of Internet-Based Marketing Channels by Small- and Medium-Sized Manufacturers
Source title: International Journal of E-Business Research (IJEBR)
Affiliations: University of Aarhus, Department of Management, School of Economics and Management, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Nielson, J.F., University of Aarhus, Department of Management, School of Economics and Management, Denmark; Host, V., University of Aarhus, Department of Management, School of Economics and Management, Denmark; Mols, N.P., University of Aarhus, Department of Management, School of Economics and Management, Denmark
Abstract: This paper analyses factors influencing manufacturers’ adoption of Internet-based marketing channels using models based on marketing channel and organisational innovation theory. Survey data from 1,163 Danish, Finnish, and Swedish manufacturers form the empirical basis for testing the models using LISREL analysis. The results stress that adoption of Internet-based marketing is influenced by willingness to cannibalize, by management support, by market pressure, and by a firm's knowledge of IT. A willingness to cannibalize mediates the effects of future market orientation, ownership, specialized investments, and management support. This is mainly the case in small firms, as the importance of the various drivers and the adoption pattern varies among size categories. Market-pull factors have relatively more explanatory power in medium-sized and large companies. © 2005, IGI Global. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: distribution channels; e-commerce implementation; e-commerce in SMEs; internet marketing; organizational innovation; organizational size; small to medium sized enterprises (SMEs); willingness to cannibalize

Authors: Song W., Chen D., Chung J.-Y.
Title: An investigation on using web services for micro-payment
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Computer Science, Durham University, Durham, United Kingdom; Computer Science, Zhejiang University, Zhejiang, China; IBM T.J. Watson Research Center, New York, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Song, W., Computer Science, Durham University, Durham, United Kingdom; Chen, D., Computer Science, Zhejiang University, Zhejiang, China; Chung, J.-Y., IBM T.J. Watson Research Center, New York, NY, United States
Abstract: E-commerce development and applications have been bringing the Internet to business and marketing and reforming our current business styles and processes. As Business to Business (B2B) has been a main stream of the e-commerce activities for a decade, business to customer (B2C) is still a new area to explore. Among the business to customer activities, a strong impact is security, i.e., how to protect secrets of various parties in business transactions. Different security methods apply to different businesses and meet different customers' needs. The methods with low cost and easy to implement may be less secure, whereas the methods providing high level security can be unaffordable to many small enterprises and individuals. In particular, people, while browsing or surfing on the Web, wish to pay a very small amount and "buy" (perhaps just download) an interesting item from the Web. The "click-and-pay" or "click-and-buy" does not require high security protection and should be convenient to use (buy and pay). Micro-payment issue emerges from the context to meet the need of applicability of low secure and cost in e-purchase. Payments of small amounts may enable many exciting applications on the Internet, such as selling information, small software and services. Users are willing to pay a small amount of money for the information, software and services. While the payment is small, expensive security protection is unnecessary. What users require may include negligible delay, rapid click-through, and automatic billing. Micro-payment is a service intensive activity, where many payment tasks involve different forms of services, such as payment method selection for buyers, security support software, product price comparison, etc. In this paper, we intend to investigate and analyze various aspects of micro-payment system using the web service technology. We will discuss business patterns for micro-payment systems using Web Services approaches. © Springer-Verlag 2004.
Index Keywords: Application programs; Costs; Electronic commerce; Internet; Sales; Websites; Business to business; Business to customers; Business transaction; E-commerce development; Investigate and analyze; Micro-payment systems; Web service technology; Web-services approach; Web services
Correspondence Address: Song, W.; Computer Science, Durham University, Durham, United Kingdom; email: w.w.song@dur.ac.uk

Title: Internet-enabled technology in knowledge-intensive business services: A comparison of Northern Ireland, the Republic of Ireland and New Zealand
Source title: Marketing Intelligence & Planning
Affiliations: University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand; University of Ulster, Coleraine, Northern Ireland, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Mccole, P., University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand; Ramsey, E., University of Ulster, Coleraine, Northern Ireland, United Kingdom
Abstract: This article reports a study of e-business adoption among SMEs in the knowledge-intensive service sector in three countries, the results of which contain a number of practical lessons and some much needed encouragement to laggards. The new spatial possibilities of internet-based technologies provide a powerful route to innovative marketing strategies. Consequently, organisations of all sizes are finding it necessary to establish a web presence to increase their ability to survive in an increasingly dynamic and competitive business environment. Strategically, firms need to be creative and innovative in order to deal effectively with the e-marketing opportunities the internet can deliver. The findings of a comparative study conducted in Northern Ireland, the Republic of Ireland and New Zealand provide evidence of primitive and localised exploitation of the technology, a general lack of enthusiasm about its possibilities, and a perception that there are many barriers to successfully adding value at the customer interface. It is hoped that the somewhat pessimistic tone of the analysis will be taken as an opportunity to win competitive advantage in the knowledge-intensive service sector, rather than a reason to postpone adoption of internet-enabled technology. © 2004, Emerald Group Publishing Limited
Author Keywords: Electronic commerce; Internet marketing; Marketing models; Small to medium-sized enterprises; Worldwide web

Authors: Fry J., Tyrrall D., Pugh G., Wyld J.
Title: The provision and accessibility of small business Web sites: A survey of independent UK breweries
Source title: Journal of Small Business and Enterprise Development
Affiliations: Accounting and Finance Research Unit, Open University Business School, Milton Keynes, United Kingdom; Cass Business School, City University, London, United Kingdom; Economics, Staffordshire University Business School, Stafford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Fry, J., Accounting and Finance Research Unit, Open University Business School, Milton Keynes, United Kingdom; Tyrrall, D., Cass Business School, City University, London, United Kingdom; Pugh, G., Economics, Staffordshire University Business School, Stafford, United Kingdom; Wyld, J., Economics, Staffordshire University Business School, Stafford, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper surveys the population of independent breweries in the UK to ascertain their Web site usage and accessibility via the Internet. It finds independent breweries have tended to lag similarly sized business in other sectors in the provision or abandonment of company Web sites. Most of their Web sites have intuitively easy URLs and are readily accessible via brewery directories, but are less accessible via popular search engines. Most are corporate Web sites rather than marketing or selling tools. The paper concludes with a discussion of business and policy implications for small businesses and the Internet. © 2004, Emerald Group Publishing Limited

Title: Net profits: Using the Web to boost your business
Source title: Screen Printing
Affiliations: Academy of Screen Printing Technology; Union Ink Co., Inc.
Authors with affiliations: Ukena, M., Academy of Screen Printing Technology, Union Ink Co., Inc.
Abstract: Several small screen printing companies are using Internet marketing for a variety of products and services to reach a broader customers base and gain significant recognition in little time. Before making such a move, the companies must look for certain issues like Web presentation, role of a third party in the collection of payments, general credit and payment policy, services available, lead time, and contact details. Various resources one must look into before launching a web site are finding a domain name, finding a hosting service (the Internet service provider) and development of the Webster itself. The homepage presentation, ease of navigation, shopping cart, catalog, and provision for visitors response have to be taken care of in the development process. Regular updation and changes in the Webster are required if it is expected that the visiting frequency is high. The decision to get the web page developed by a web programmer or by one's own staff also plays an important role.
Index Keywords: Internet; Marketing; Pattern recognition; Public policy; Homepage presentation; Internet service provider); Payment policy; Screen printing companies; Screen printing; Internet; Marketing; Navigational Equipment; Silk Screen Printing

Title: Internet Adoption by Entrepreneurial Small Firms (ESF’s): Purchasing Versus Non-Purchasing Behaviors
Source title: Journal of Research in Marketing and Entrepreneurship
Affiliations: West Chester University, United States; Mercer University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Patrick, M.L., West Chester University, United States; Miller, G.L., Mercer University, United States
Abstract: Current models of Internet adoption at the marketing/entrepreneurship interface focus on the Entrepreneurial Small Firm (ESF) as the supplier in a supplier/buyer relationship. Analysis of a data set, which captured selected ESF Internet buying behaviours, offers insights from the buyer perspective. The authors present these findings and propose implications for the supplier/buyer relationship. © 2004, Emerald Group Publishing Limited
Author Keywords: Adoption; Behaviour; Internet

Title: Online marketing - Part II
Source title: Quick Printing
Authors with affiliations: Lautenslager, A.
Abstract: The use of email, an online activity, in marketing is discussed. For most small businesses, permission-based email marketing campaigns are the cost-effective ways to reach customers. This can consist of email newsletters or targeted personalized email messages. Email marketing can be a tool for branding, direct response, and building relationships. It is cheap, easy to use, and almost everyone has an email address. Email marketing includes sending direct promotional emails to interested prospects and providing information to acquire new customers or to sell to existing customers. It can also be used to keep in touch with customers, to encourage customer loyalty, and to further customer relationships.

Authors: Fillis I., Johannson U., Wagner B.
Title: Factors impacting on e-business adoption and development in the smaller firm
Source title: International Journal of Entrepreneurial Behaviour & Research
Affiliations: Department of Marketing, Faculty of Management, University of Stirling, Stirling, United Kingdom; Department of Business Administration, Lund University, Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Fillis, I., Department of Marketing, Faculty of Management, University of Stirling, Stirling, United Kingdom; Johannson, U., Department of Business Administration, Lund University, Lund, Sweden; Wagner, B., Department of Marketing, Faculty of Management, University of Stirling, Stirling, United Kingdom
Abstract: Globalisation and technology effects appear to have spurred smaller firms around the world to embrace e-business practices. However, there is considerable variability in adoption and usage from country to country. Drawing on existing research on e-business and conventional business and marketing in the smaller firm, this paper formulates a conceptual framework of reasons behind adoption and non-adoption in the smaller firm. Macro dimensions, industry sector and firm-level factors are analysed, together with owner/manager motivations and attitudes towards e-business adoption. A conceptual framework is constructed and research propositions are then developed in order to focus attention on sets of internal and external factors which impact on smaller firm e-business usage. Recommendations for future theory development are presented, together with implications for industry bodies involved in supporting the SME sector. © 2004, Emerald Group Publishing Limited
Author Keywords: Competences; Electronic commerce; Entrepreneurs; Internet marketing; Small to medium-sized enterprises

Title: Internet marketing in exports - A useful tool for small businesses
Source title: Small Enterprise Development
Authors with affiliations: Merlin, B.
Abstract: Internet marketing is on the rise, and developing country export companies can use it to overcome some of their competitive disadvantages. This article describes a study of small and medium-sized exporters in the wine industry in Chile and the coffee industry in Costa Rica. In Chile, extranets were found to be useful for communicating with importers around the world and providing marketing materials; in Costa Rica, some exporters found online shops to be a good way of increasing turnover with higher margins. Constraints to the adoption of internet marketing are discussed.
Index Keywords: export; international comparison; Internet; marketing; small scale industry; technological development; telecommunication

Title: The use of information and communication technologies as a critical success factor for marketing in Turkish agri-food companies
Source title: Food Reviews International
Affiliations: Uludag University, Faculty of Agriculture, Department of Agricultural Economics, Bursa, Turkey; Uludag University, Faculty of Agriculture, Department of Agricultural Economics, Bursa 16059, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Çetin, B., Uludag University, Faculty of Agriculture, Department of Agricultural Economics, Bursa, Turkey, Uludag University, Faculty of Agriculture, Department of Agricultural Economics, Bursa 16059, Turkey; Akpinar, A., Uludag University, Faculty of Agriculture, Department of Agricultural Economics, Bursa, Turkey; Ozsaym, D., Uludag University, Faculty of Agriculture, Department of Agricultural Economics, Bursa, Turkey
Abstract: In the mid to late 1980s, the rapid growth in computer networks and online services directed companies, including those in the agri-food industry, to use information and communication technologies (ICT). As a result of this progress, small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs) need to change to remain competitive in the rapidly changing business environment of the twenty-first century through the use of Internet and Web sites. The use of ICT as communication and marketing platforms provides agri-food SMEs considerable advantage. The main aim of this article is to examine the impact of the Internet and Web sites on the marketing of Turkish agri-food SMEs and to obtain information about the uses of ICT by these firms. This is reported by a two-stage survey undertaken by the Turkish agri-food directorate (KOBI).
Author Keywords: Agri-food; Internet; Marketing; Small and medium sized enterprises
Index Keywords: Competition; Electronic commerce; Food products plants; Information technology; International trade; Internet; Marketing; Societies and institutions; Agri-food; Communication technologies; Small and medium sized enterprises; Turkish agri-food companies; Agricultural products

Title: Multi-location organisation in the service sector: An exploratory study of small advertising businesses in cities [Multiple Standortorganisation in der Dienstleistungswirtschaft: Explorative Studie anhand von städtischen Kleinbetrieben der Werbewirtschaft]
Source title: Wirtschaftsgeographische Studien
Authors with affiliations: Faustmann, R.
Abstract: Starting from the statement that in economic geography up to now the processes of service production itself have hardly been studied in detail, the author traces the actual production processes in two small firms of the advertising industry - one mainly engaged in print media, the other in internet advertising - both located in Vienna. The theoretical basis of the study is the model of 'function-related location orientation' ("Modell der funktionsaffinen Standortorientierung") first published by Staudacher (1991). By means of a diary-like protocol method (combined with participating observation) the single steps of production are recorded in detail, thus enabling an analysis, including graphical visualisation, of the following aspects: How many contacts occur, who are the contact partners (internal/external service producers, machines, the client)? Are the contacts direct or indirect, face-to-face or via IT media? Where do the contacts take place (in the advertising firm, at external producers, with the client)? - In sum, the study provides deeper insight into contact intensity, media utilisation, location dependence and other characteristics of intermediate service production in European cities. The study's own findings are systematically contrasted with the pertinent geographic and business literature.
Index Keywords: advertising; industrial practice; production system; service sector; Austria; Central Europe; Eurasia; Europe; Vienna

Authors: Jones C., Hecker R., Holland P.
Title: Small firm Internet adoption: Opportunities forgone, a journey not begun
Source title: Journal of Small Business and Enterprise Development
Affiliations: School of Management, University of Tasmania, Hobart, Australia; Department of Management, Faculty of Business and Economics, Monash University, Victoria, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Jones, C., School of Management, University of Tasmania, Hobart, Australia; Hecker, R., School of Management, University of Tasmania, Hobart, Australia; Holland, P., Department of Management, Faculty of Business and Economics, Monash University, Victoria, Australia
Abstract: This paper explores the endeavours of five small firms to develop Web-based commerce capabilities within their existing operations. The focus is on the strategic acquisition and exploitation of knowledge which underpins new value creating activities related to Web-based commerce. A normative Web-based commerce adoption model developed from a review of the extant literature related to electronic marketing, entrepreneurship, and the diffusion of new innovations was empirically tested. A multiple case study design enabled the exploration of contemporary marketing and entrepreneurship issues within the real life context of five small firms. The model aimed to emphasis best-practice adoption methods emphasizing the value of a firm’s market orientation and entrepreneurial capabilities. A preliminary test of the model’s theoretical contentions lent support to its overall focus, but found that the firm’s existing learning capabilities were diminished during the adoption of Web-based commerce, and that a lack of vision and prior knowledge produced sub-optimal adoption outcomes. © 2003, MCB UP Limited
Author Keywords: Australia; Electronic commerce; Entrepreneurialism; Internet marketing; Market orientation; Small- to medium-sized enterprises

Authors: Moen Ø., Endresen I., Gavlen M.
Title: Executive Insights: Use of the Internet in International Marketing: A Case Study of Small Computer Software Firms
Source title: Journal of International Marketing
Affiliations: Department of Industrial Economics, Norwegian Inst. of Sci./Technology, Norway; WeatherOne AS, Oslo, Norway; Global Arch./Core Technologies Group, Accenture, Sophia Antipolis, France
Authors with affiliations: Moen, Ø., Department of Industrial Economics, Norwegian Inst. of Sci./Technology, Norway; Endresen, I., WeatherOne AS, Oslo, Norway; Gavlen, M., Global Arch./Core Technologies Group, Accenture, Sophia Antipolis, France
Abstract: This study focuses on how small exporting firms use the Internet in their international marketing activities. The authors conducted six case studies of software firms. The software sector has several notable features: It is one of the world's fastest-growing industries, its products can be distributed electronically, and software companies are "Internet literate." This study's findings suggest that most firms use the Internet to search for information about customers, distributors, and partners. The Internet does not replace personal sales; most firms reported a rather complex purchasing process and an extensive need for communication with customers before the purchase decision. The authors found standardized products to be most suited for Internet-based sales; however, standardization reduced firms' competitive advantage and profit margins. Software firms' most significant use of the Internet was for postsales service and support activities; these activities both generated revenue and improved customer relations. Partnership agreements with well-known firms, positive product reviews, and image building through the Internet were important to most firms in order to reduce the uncertainty that potential customers often experience when unknown suppliers offer unfamiliar products. The authors also discuss implications for managers in industrial sectors other than software.

Title: Application of P2P (Peer-to-Peer) technology to marketing
Source title: Proceedings - 2003 International Conference on Cyberworlds, CW 2003
Affiliations: Graduate School of Human Informatics, Nagoya University, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kato, T., Graduate School of Human Informatics, Nagoya University, Japan; Yokoi, S., Graduate School of Human Informatics, Nagoya University, Japan
Abstract: Peer-to-Peer (P2P) networks are spreading, and their practical applications for the business scene are promising. However, the essence of P2P is missed by broad interpretations that do not make it a problem whether to use P2P technology. Incidentally, although marketing activity currently consists mainly of Web pages or mail, it is difficult to actively find latent customers from the company side, and it is not necessarily an effective marketing means for a small-scale company. Therefore, in this paper, we discuss the application of P2P technology to marketing. First, the essence of P2P is correctly extracted by focusing on the state of the information that changes within a P2P network, and effective fields in business are clarified. Next, by paying attention to characteristics of P2P that have not yet been adequately developed in business, we have recognized that P2P marketing is promising from now on. We devise five models for applying P2P networks to the marketing field (P2P marketing), and clarify P2P's marketing features through comparisons with existing Internet marketing. Consequently, we reveal features not currently held by Web pages or mail. © 2003 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Commerce; Distributed computer systems; Marketing; Websites; Effective field; Internet marketing; Marketing activities; Marketing field; Marketing IS; P2P (peer to peer); P2P technologies; Peer to Peer (P2P) network; Peer to peer networks
Publisher: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc.

Title: IFIP TC8/WG8.4 2nd Working Conference on E-Business: Multidisciplinary Research and Practice
Source title: IFIP Advances in Information and Communication Technology
Abstract: The proceedings contain 35 papers. The special focus in this conference is on E-Business. The topics include: The internet and an opportunity to re-invent the banking system; failing with success; models of trust in business-to-consumer electronic commerce; conceptual frames of reference and their influence on E-commerce system development; enhancing mobile commerce; E-business and dot.com driven transformation - a comparison of Australian and Indian experiences in the telecom sector; a strategic comprehensive framework for evaluating is investments; a strategy for small and medium size enterprise adoption of e-business practices in Atlantic Canada; the potentialities of focus groups in e-business research; use of the web for destination marketing by regional tourism organisations in the Asia-pacific region; internet marketing communications; E-business and the formation of strategies; managing a portfolio of supplier relations in internet-driven electronic market places; E-government business strategies and services to citizens; the implications of E-commerce for software project risk; integrating E-commerce into the retail supply chain; integration of an internet-driven supply chain for a medium-size E-commerce company; an investigation into the success factors; governance for E-business knowledge management systems; E-commerce and human resource management; designing an online self-assessment tool utilizing confidence measurement; strategizing for distributed knowledge management; understanding e-business competencies in SMEs; traditional Australian media organisations adoption of the world wide web; the nature of work for employees in a virtual organisation and mobile commerce - the challenges.
Abbreviated Source Title: IFIP Advances in Information and Communication Technology

Title: Cause-Related marketing via the world wide web: A relationship marketing strategy
Source title: Journal of Nonprofit and Public Sector Marketing
Affiliations: School of Business and Economics, Lynchburg College, VA, United States; School of Business and Economics, Lynchburg College, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Husted, S.W., School of Business and Economics, Lynchburg College, VA, United States; Whitehouse, F.R., Jr., School of Business and Economics, Lynchburg College, VA, United States
Abstract: This paper explores how a small sample of companies are using cause-related marketing and the World Wide Web to support their relationship marketing strategies. The use of corporate social responsibility appeals, whether espousal of or support for socially salient causes, in the design and execution of marketing communication campaigns is developed. The integration of the Internet and company-sponsored websites into cause-related campaigns is discussed. Principles which may govern the use of causes in Web-based campaigns are introduced and the Web efforts of five well-known companies are reviewed. Twelve recommendations are made regarding the effective use of the Web in cause-related marketing efforts. © 2002 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cause related marketing; Corporate social responsibility; Internet; Relationship marketing; Social responsibility marketing; World Wide Web

Authors: Rogers M., Chesney T., Raeburn S.
Title: E-procurement in a rural area
Source title: ICEIS 2002 - Proceedings of the 4th International Conference on Enterprise Information Systems
Affiliations: Social Computing Group, School of Computing, Napier University, Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Rogers, M., Social Computing Group, School of Computing, Napier University, Edinburgh, United Kingdom; Chesney, T., Social Computing Group, School of Computing, Napier University, Edinburgh, United Kingdom; Raeburn, S., Social Computing Group, School of Computing, Napier University, Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Abstract: E-procurement has great potential to become a major way of transacting in rural areas such as the Scottish Borders where the variety of shops and services offered is limited. The Scottish Borders Council has selected e-procurement as a means to reduce costs, improve process and service delivery, meet Government targets for electronic purchasing and, not least, use e-procurement to assist local businesses in this economically depressed region to become e-commerce capable, thus improving their ability to grow and create wealth and employment in the region. This paper reports the results of research conducted to establish whether recruiting suppliers to e-commerce is likely to be problematic for the Council. Findings show that in terms of connectivity, the Scottish Borders appear ahead of the rest of the UK which is encouraging for the Borders economy and for the Council's e-procurement strategy, although no data is available on actual usage of the Internet, only that the firms have a connection. Fewer of the smaller firms are using the Internet as a marketing tool, that is they do not have even a web site with information only content. The use of ecommerce among Council suppliers is well below the UK average. A number of factors appear to be holding them back. These are discussed.
Author Keywords: E-commerce; E-marketplace; Economically depressed region; Small business
Index Keywords: Commerce; Electronic commerce; Information systems; Internet; Rural areas; E-marketplaces; e-Procurement; Economically depressed region; Local business; Marketing tools; Number of factors; Service delivery; Small business; Supply chains

Authors: Illingworth L., Williams D., Burnett S.
Title: The costs and benefits of the Internet as a marketing and communications tool: The attitudes, perceptions and experiences within the non-profit environmental sector in Scotland
Source title: Aslib Proceedings
Affiliations: Centre for Knowledge Management, Robert Gordon University, Aberdeen, United Kingdom; School of Information and Media, Robert Gordon University, Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Illingworth, L., Centre for Knowledge Management, Robert Gordon University, Aberdeen, United Kingdom; Williams, D., School of Information and Media, Robert Gordon University, Aberdeen, United Kingdom; Burnett, S., Centre for Knowledge Management, Robert Gordon University, Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Abstract: Discusses the findings of a study investigating the attitudes, perceptions and experiences of Scottish non-profit environmental organisations and the costs and benefits of the Internet as a marketing and communications tool. Aims to ascertain whether the size of the organisation and the level of Internet use determines the perceptions and beliefs of non-profit organisations within the environmental sector in Scotland and whether these factors also determines the costs and benefits experienced by Internet users. Finds that regardless of size or the level of use, organisations believe the Internet is a cost-effective way to market their organisations and promote awareness. However, attitudinal factors affect the level of use by small organisations. Overall the organisations within the sample have indicated that the Internet is a low cost, high benefit marketing solution. © MCB UP Limited.
Author Keywords: Communications; Consumer attitudes; Internet; Marketing; Non-profit organizations; Scotland
Correspondence Address: Illingworth, L.; Centre for Knowledge Management, Robert Gordon University, Aberdeen, United Kingdom

Authors: Sparkes A., Thomas B., Clifton N., Rosales M.
Title: The Internet as a Marketing Interface for Welsh Speciality Small and Medium-sized Agri-food Enterprises
Source title: Journal of Research in Marketing and Entrepreneurship
Affiliations: Welsh Enterprise Institute, University of Glamorgan Business School, United Kingdom; Cardiff University, United Kingdom; College of Business Administration, University of South Florida, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sparkes, A., Welsh Enterprise Institute, University of Glamorgan Business School, United Kingdom; Thomas, B., Welsh Enterprise Institute, University of Glamorgan Business School, United Kingdom; Clifton, N., Cardiff University, United Kingdom; Rosales, M., College of Business Administration, University of South Florida, United States
Abstract: A major challenge facing Welsh speciality Small and Medium-sized Agri-food Enterprises (SMAFEs) is how to sustain growth in a global market. This can be enhanced through e-commerce and the marketing of product through the Internet to an international audience. Recent research carried out by the Welsh Enterprise Institute (WEI) found that there may only be 10 per cent of Welsh SMAFEs using the Internet for this purpose. The challenge, therefore, is how to enable SMAFEs to market effectively their products; to put these small firms not only in contact with local markets but also international markets; to ensure a range of “authentic” food products is available to Welsh communities in other countries and those people with affinity to “all things Welsh”; and to establish channels that facilitate repeat purchase by visitors to Wales. This challenge can be responded to by enabling SMAFEs to gain access to the Internet and to be confidence in its use, to develop “user friendly” Web sites, to link to overseas markets through the Internet, and to establish a long-term customer base. The WEI has undertaken a two stage survey to measure SMAFE usage of e-mail and the Internet in Wales. The buying habits of Welsh Affinity Groups (WAGs) on the Internet in the USA, Canada and other countries has also been studied and it is planned to establish network links between the SMAFEs and the WAGs, and communities overseas. This paper describes the survey of SMAFEs in Wales and reports on the analysis of the findings together with recommendations for the establishment of a comprehensive Welsh food portal. This is related to the study of the WAGs in the USA and Canada and a proposal for the development of a virtual “market place” between the SMAFEs and the WAGs is explored. The WEI has joined forces with Web design companies WebAware and MAWR Ltd., to offer high quality consultancy and advice to provide Web site and e-commerce solutions relevant to SMAFEs to create an anticipated multi-million pound net gain to Wales and the Welsh Agri-food sector through world-wide sales. A Welsh food portal is therefore of immense importance as a marketing entrepreneurship interfacing tool not only to Agri-food enterprises in Wales but also to customers from across the World. The paper concludes by arguing for the need for appropriate support to be provided for speciality Welsh SMAFEs to make them aware of the importance of the adoption of e-commerce including the Internet and Web sites. This paper is a version of one that has been published in the International Journal of Applied Marketing, published by International Marketing Journals, ISSN: 1742-2612. © 2001, MCB UP Limited
Author Keywords: Agricultural and food technology; Small to medium sized enterprises; Wales

Title: Online branding: An antipodean experience
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: CEO, Jack Yan and Associates, PO Box 14-368, Wellington, 6041, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Yan, J., CEO, Jack Yan and Associates, PO Box 14-368, Wellington, 6041, New Zealand
Abstract: Australia and New Zealand enjoy high per-capita internet usage and have a small group of organizations that have succeeded globally on the web despite less capitalization and fewer resources. The author, a web pioneer and identity expert, examines how they have instead leveraged brands and intellectual capital, and looks at implications for all firms wishing to incorporate a web element to their marketing. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2001.
Index Keywords: Knowledge management; Australia; Intellectual capital; Internet usage; New zealand; Per capita; Internet

Title: Developing an online access strategy: Issues facing small to medium-sized tourism and hospitality enterprises
Source title: Journal of Vacation Marketing
Affiliations: PO Box 584, Byron Bay, NSW 2481, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Christian, R., PO Box 584, Byron Bay, NSW 2481, Australia
Abstract: This paper examines the use of the Internet as a marketing and promotional tool within the tourism and hospitality industries. Taking the situation in Australia as an example, the use of the Internet as a promotional tool has not taken hold among small to medium tourism enterprises. It has been suggested that this reluctance to embrace the Internet is due to a range of impediments such as high costs and issues related to adopting new technologies. This paper suggests that a poor understanding of the technology combined with the plethora of jargon and confusing information concerning Internet marketing and promotion is more likely to be the main cause of the slow uptake. This paper also outlines some of the main considerations in developing a site and/or choosing a special-interest site or portal to join. Finally, the case of a special-interest site that serves small to medium businesses is looked at. © Henry Stewart Publications.
Author Keywords: Byron Bay; Internet; marketing; portal; tourism
Correspondence Address: Christian, R.; PO Box 584, Byron Bay, NSW 2481, Australia; email: rickchristian@travelpromote.com.au

Title: Internet technology leads way into the new millennium
Source title: Wood Technology
Affiliations: Decision Dynamics Inc, Lake Oswego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Byers, Ken, Decision Dynamics Inc, Lake Oswego, United States; Plummer, Terry, Decision Dynamics Inc, Lake Oswego, United States
Abstract: The Internet has made information and communication accessible without time, place or format constraints. Current technologies and applications have enabled large, mid-size, and small companies to participate on an equal basis, changing the paradigm of how business is conducted. Internet also helps wood processors in supporting business decisions and in supporting new ways of marketing to and relating with customers.
Index Keywords: Data communication systems; Decision support systems; Electronic commerce; Industrial economics; Marketing; World Wide Web; Web marketing; Wood
Correspondence Address: Byers, Ken; Decision Dynamics Inc, Lake Oswego, United States

Title: A Longitudinal Study of Expectations in Small Business Internet Commerce
Source title: International Journal of Electronic Commerce
Authors with affiliations: Poon, S.; Swatman, P.
Abstract: This paper examines the gap between expectation and realization among a group of small Australian firms that engaged in small business Internet commerce (SBIC) over a 20-month period. Essentially, small firms on-line believed that the Internet is important in terms of competitiveness, although some of their early expectations about the ability of SBIC to generate instant competitive advantage had began to wane. The most useful effects of the Internet were in information gathering and time savings, but results in advertising and sales were less encouraging. Internet marketing effectiveness was found to be industry-sector-dependent.
Author Keywords: Electronic commerce; Internet commerce; Small business internet commerce

Title: The internet as a marketing tool
Source title: The 79th World Conference of The Textile Institute, 10th-13th February 1999, Chennai, India - volume 2
Affiliations: Computer Clothing Research Ctr, Nottingham Trent University, Burton Street, Nottingham NG1 4BU, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Gray, S., Computer Clothing Research Ctr, Nottingham Trent University, Burton Street, Nottingham NG1 4BU, United Kingdom
Abstract: The clothing and textiles industry sets new fashion trends. The Internet is the new information technology trend. Companies are starting to use the Internet as a tool that enables them to promote their products and to find information. The Internet knows no boundaries and it is rapidly becoming the definitive way to make new contacts and develop new markets. The technology can make a small company look very impressive and can also help organisations to develop niche markets. The customer is king. Shopping is an experience that can cause pleasure and pain. For many people nothing will change their need for a trip to the high street or mall. A large number of people buy from catalogues and there is a growing band who can shop from their PC using electronic services. Retailers are always looking at new ways of differentiating themselves from their competitors. Many of them now have Internet sites, each with its own particular focus and aesthetic appeal. Most of these sites are relatively new and therefore retailers have very limited experience of the technology and are just starting to obtain feedback from customers. For them 'interactive' customers are simply viewers of their pages, and feedback coming in the form of orders for products displayed therein. Manufacturers of apparel have had mixed fortunes with Internet marketing. Some made significant investments in the creation of web sites and found the impact on their business was minimal, others (usually the specialist companies that sell direct to the public) fared better. The organisations that have adopted Internet sales services have been the machinery suppliers and those offering goods and services to the sector. To date retailers have not really exploited the full potential of digital technology and many lessons can be learned, not least those from the broadcasting and production industries. There is enormous scope for retailers to become major users of broadband links to home and office, exploiting cable communications in novel ways, each designed to attract customers to their particular goods and services. Other groups such as magazine publishers and show promoters are using the Internet as an additional means of promoting their existing products. Recently there have been new products hitting the market, designed specially for the sector. These centre on up-to-the-minute fashion information including trend forecasting and immediate feedback from shows and shopping centres. Although currently expensive these services are set to change the ways in which information will be delivered to the increasingly global fashion industry.
Index Keywords: internet; marketing; research and development; textile-clothing industry
Correspondence Address: Gray, S.; Computer Clothing Research Ctr, Nottingham Trent University, Burton Street, Nottingham NG1 4BU, United Kingdom
Publisher: The textile Institute The Textile Institute

Title: Internet-enabled international marketing: A small business network perspective
Source title: Journal of Marketing Management
Affiliations: School of Information Systems, Swinburne University of Technology, John St. Hawthorn, VIC, Australia; School of Management, Swinburne University of Technology, John St. Hawthorn, VIC, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Poon, S., School of Information Systems, Swinburne University of Technology, John St. Hawthorn, VIC, Australia; Jevons, C., School of Management, Swinburne University of Technology, John St. Hawthorn, VIC, Australia
Abstract: Many small businesses in the 1990s are compelled to compete beyond their comfort zone (local markets) due to the globalization and internationalization of the marketplace. At the same time, the commercialization of the Internet has created unprecedented opportunities for small businesses to engage in national and international marketing campaigns which could have been unaffordable due to the huge amount of resources required. This paper discusses why the Internet is particularly important for small business international marketing. It then investigates how small business network exchange can be initiated and supported using the Internet, which in turn provides a platform for international marketing. It abo explores strategies for carrying out marketing activities on the Internet, considering the different kinds of inter-organizational relationships that exist within small business networks. Finally, it is argued that marketing is only one aspect of how small business networks can gain strategic advantage in using the Internet. The fundamental issue is to build useful inter-organizational systems to support not only marketing activities among small businesses on the Internet but also to transform activities on different parts of the small business value chain. © 1997 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Correspondence Address: Poon, S.; School of Information Systems, Swinburne University of Technology, John St. Hawthorn, VIC, Australia

Title: Internet marketing in the internationalisation of UK SMEs
Source title: Journal of Marketing Management
Affiliations: Department of Marketing, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hamill, J., Department of Marketing, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, United Kingdom; Gregory, K., Department of Marketing, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper presents the preliminary results of a large-scale survey which examined Internet marketing applications in the inter-nationalisation of UK SMEs. Although there are some examples of innovative practice, few UK SMEs are utilising the full potential of the World Wide Web (WWW) in international marketing. In this respect, practice in the UK lags several years behind that in the US. Given that the Internet will have a revolutionary impact on the conduct of international trade, a major education and training initiative is required to improve knowledge and understanding in this area and to encourage more effective use of the Internet to support SME internationalisation. In the absence of such an initiative, a further decline in the UK's international competitive position can be expected as other nations embrace the global marketing opportunities made possible by the Web. © 1997 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Correspondence Address: Hamill, J.; Department of Marketing, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, G4 0RQ, United Kingdom; email: jimh@market.srrath.ac.uk

Title: ICL company research and development. Part 3. The new range and other developments, 1968-85
Source title: ICL technical journal
Affiliations: Univ of Warwick, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Campbell-Kelly, Martin, Univ of Warwick, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper describes the principal R&D activities in ICL from its formation in 1968 up to the STC takeover in 1984. For much of this period, R&D was strongly focused on the development and subsequent enhancement of a new range of computers, launched as the ICL 2900 series in 1974, and relaunched as Series 39 in 1985. The development of the new range made enormous demands on every division of ICL, and caused the company to neglect other aspects of the computer business, such as small business systems and networks. Consequently, ICL's emphasis on mainframes left it ill-prepared to meet the challenges of the 1980s. The paper concludes with a discussion of the management changes and the new product and marketing strategies that helped to achieve ICL's recovery during 1981-84.
Index Keywords: Computer Systems, Digital--Marketing; Industrial Economics; Computer Firm; International Market; Mainframes; Industrial Management
Correspondence Address: Campbell-Kelly, Martin; Univ of WarwickUnited Kingdom
